intro.value: You know Karen. You’ve seen her at Red Lobster, the ballpark, and stuck in traffic.

But how did Karen become Karen — an entitled middle-aged white woman who needs to speak to the manager? According to baby name data from the Social Security Administration (SSA), Karen first appeared in the female Top 20 in 1941 and spent 30 years there until it dropped out in 1971. By the 1990s, Karen had fallen out of the Top 100.

Chances are you don’t know too many Karens today, but when Karen hit it’s peak at #3 in 1965 Karens were everywhere. It’s this swift decay in popularity that’s made Karen so era defining (like Patricia before her, and Shirley before her) and that’s why the name has found new notoriety as a pejorative meme. Karen has become the perfect caricature of women of a certain age and a certain privilege.

Charting Karen’s trajectory got us thinking: are there other names that are equally as Karen as Karen? First we gathered baby names from 1918–2018. Then we dropped any name that never made it to the Top 20 (to account for popularity) and didn’t appear in the top list at least half of the years, or 50 out of 100 (to account for longevity). That left us with 129 female names and 76 male names (yes, we’re going there too!) to test correlation. Names that have a strong correlation, or above 0.7 were included. So, without further ado, introducing...

otherFKarens.value: Female Karens Recently there’s been debate about if Karen is a racist or sexist slur akin to using the n-word. We’re here to tell you it’s not. Don’t believe us? Take it from a Karen herself. But, if you’re seriously tired of seeing the name Karen everywhere, we’ve got you covered. Here are the names to use instead. (Our apologies to all the Deborahs, Debbies, and Debras.)

otherMKarens.value: Male Karens Karen is largely reserved for women (white women), but is there a male equivalent? Maybe it’s Ian, like Urban Dictionary suggests. Or maybe it’s Rand of Middle Class Fancy fame. Or maybe it’s simply Greg. Wrong, it’s definitely one of these names.

compare.value: Now you know which names have the potential to become tomorrow’s next viral punchline, but what about the next generation of Karens. Is it really Becky?
Looking ahead 10, 20, and 30 years, we’ve calculated which names have a similar trajectory and strong correlation to Karen.

futureFKarens.value: Female Karens Turns out, it’s not “BBQ Becky” or “Becky with the good hair” that you’ll need to watch out for in .

futureMKarens.value: Male Karens Of course we’re future proofing you for male names too. Here are ones in the danger zone in .
